author: Rose Powell
title: $A rebounds as yuan enters 'comfort zone'
text:
The Australian dollar recovered within minutes as the offshore yuan failed to fall dramatically, raising hopes the market was stabilising. Louie Douvis Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Rose Powell
The Australian dollar rebounded on Thursday on hopes China will not let the yuan depreciate more after its central bank stepped up its verbal support for the currency and said there was no basis for further weakening, given strong economic fundamentals
The dollar began the day at US73.8¢, up significantly from its low of US72.15¢ on Wednesday, to around the levels at which it traded before the People's Bank of China shocked markets on Tuesday with a "one-off" currency devaluation.
The Aussie did plunge half a US cent to US73.3¢ immediately after China lowered the yuan's fixing rate by another 1.1 per cent on Thursday morning, but within minutes had rallied to above US74¢, before settling at US73.9¢ in late afternoon trade.
China's three consecutive drops in the fixing rate have now shaved more than 4 per cent off the yuan since Monday. But the currency on Thursday morning reacted less dramatically to the lower target, raising hopes the market was stabilising.
Yuan declines eased after central bank intervention on Wednesday night signalled to traders that China will control the pace of depreciation to limit capital outflows.
A press conference by the People's Bank of China on Thursday also helped calm investors.
"There's no basis for the depreciation to persist," PBOC assistant governor Zhang Xiaohui said at the rare briefing on the currency in Beijing. The adjustment spurred by Tuesday's change to how the PBOC determines the yuan's daily reference rate was basically already completed, she said.

"Trust the market, respect the market, fear the market, and follow the market," said the deputy governor, who is also in charge of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange.
Calmer waters ahead for the yuan TD Securities chief Asia-Pacific macro foreign exchange strategist Annette Beacher said the currency volatility could be calming down as the yuan entered a "new comfort zone" for the People's Bank of China.
"With a fix of 6.4010 [yuan per US dollar] there was the briefest of reactions when the markets saw the 'four' but then quickly settled when it was clear that the pace of appreciation was slowing," Ms Beacher said.
"We suspect this more measured depreciation, combined with the People's Bank of China's willingness to intervene to smooth this more market-based regime, will see [more measured moves in the currency] as the session unfolds."
US economic data to be released on Thursday night could even see the dollar lodge above US74¢, ThinkForex senior market analyst Matt Simpson said
"With volatility and whipsaws the theme of the week, the markets will now shift focus to [Thursday night's] retail sales and employment data from the US," Mr Simpson said.
"Judging by the recovery from Australian dollar on Thursday, any weakness in data could see it break back above US74¢, a number which seemed unachievable as recently as Wednesday."
While the People's Bank of China's intervention late on Wednesday and slightly stronger commodity prices helped buoy the Aussie dollar, it would still continue to head down by the end of the year, Commonwealth Bank chief currency strategist Richard Grace said.
The Commonwealth Bank forecasts the local unit will fetch US73¢ by the end of September, and US70¢ by the end of the year.
"It's quite plausible it remains range-bound through to the end of the year and only drops when the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates," Mr Grace said.
"This will put additional pressure on the dollar and we do expect it to dip below US70¢ briefly, although we don't think the US dollar will continue to strengthen after the Fed raises rates, so it could level out."
